channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-11516] Track time spent in executing coprocessors in each region.
item.description: Currently, the time spent in executing coprocessors is not yet being tracked. This feature can be handy for debugging coprocessors in case of any trouble.
item.summary: Track time spent in executing coprocessors in each region.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12655685/HBASE-11516.patch
against trunk revision .
ATTACHMENT ID: 12655685

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

-1 tests included. The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

-1 patch. The patch command could not apply the patch.

Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/10066//console

This message is automatically generated.

Not checked the patch. +1 for the idea. Good on you.
I will see the patch some time later today.
Seems QA can't apply the patch !!!!

I like the idea but not the proposed changes.

Suggestions

1) Expose this as a metric instead of changes to ClusterStatus.

or

2) When changing ClusterStatus make it easy to add more metrics like this over time, something like:

repeated Metric metrics = 16;



message Metric {

    required string name = 1;

    required uint64 value = 2;

}

I'd prefer option 1. I don't think we should be passing metrics through ClusterStatus. However, if consensus opinion is we can and should do that here, then I prefer option 2 over the current patch.

Agree w/ Andy on not using ClusterStatus. We are making the info twice, once to emit via metrics and then again to put on the ClusterStatus message. ClusterStatus should die and master should consume metrics.
Thanks folks for taking a look. Sure, I would upload a new patch as per first option suggested by Andrew Purtell.

ClusterStatus should die and master should consume metrics.

That's great, used it to file HBASE-11519
Adding new patch, which implements coprocessor time as a part of metrics framework.

Why not track coprocessor upcall latency the same way we track HFile read and write op latencies? Start with HFile.java, look for the 'LATENCY_BUFFER_SIZE' constant, surrounding members and methods, and related code. This will aggregate the latency of all upcalls to all coprocessors over the metrics reporting period, but that would be more actionable then a single global incrementing counter in my opinion. You could further refine this by tracking latencies using a small sample buffer in the coprocessor environment instead of with a global sample buffer and report them per coprocessor class.

Thinking about this more, we could easily do orders of magnitude more coprocessor upcalls than HFile reads and writes and so using single aromic variables for counting will have a big perf impact. Should consider something like Click's high scale counters. Boundary has a maintained bug fixed version possibly worth moving to.

If you'd like to try this while keeping all of the above in mind, great. If not, that's fine also, please reassign to me and I'll take it up.
Andrew Purtell I will definitely try incorporating all the suggestions made. But if things are not working out at my end, I would go ahead and reassign this back to you.
Hi Srikanth Srungarapu, how is it going?
Andrew Purtell Apologies for being late as got knocked down by other tasks. Will upload a new patch no later by this weekend.
Thanks for that. The reason I ask is this is something I'm very interested seeing happen so am happy to help any way I can. Thanks again!
Attaching the screenshot of region server web ui and new patch as per suggestions.

v3 patch looks pretty good. UI updates look great. 


@@ -2357,4 +2523,19 @@ public class RegionCoprocessorHost

     }

     return tracker;

   }

+

+  public Map<String, Long> getCoprocessorExecutionTimes() {

+    Map<String, Long> results = new HashMap<String, Long>();

+    for (RegionEnvironment env : coprocessors) {

+      if (env.getInstance() instanceof RegionObserver) {

+        long total = 0;

+        for (Long time : env.getExecutionLatenciesNanos()) {

+          total += time;

+        }

+        total /= 1000;

+        results.put(env.getInstance().getClass().getSimpleName(), total);

+      }

+    }

+    return results;

+  }

This only sums the sampled execution times. I think this will be misleading because the measure won't be the real total time executing in the coprocessor over the reporting period if we ran out of space in the sample queue. We can report useful statistics using the samples though. Consider DescriptiveStatistics from commons-math, we are using it elsewhere. It's not threadsafe so shouldn't be used in place of the sample buffer, but can be used in getCoprocessorExecutionTimes when iterating through the samples. With DescriptiveStatistics we can get min, max, avg, various percentiles, e.g. 95th, 99th.

It might make more sense to rename getCoprocessorExecutionTimes to getCoprocessorExecutionStatistics or similar.
Incorporated descriptive statistics changes instead of execution time. Also made minor changes to UI to accommodate the metrics.

+1 v4 patch looks good.

There is a minor spelling error "Stastics" that would surface in metrics reports but I will fix that on commit. Or please feel free to upload a v5 patch with the fix.

Ping Enis Soztutar for branch-1.
Andrew Purtell It would be great if you can fix it while committing . Thanks so much for taking keen interest in this jira.
Thank you very much for the patch and for being receptive to feedback Srikanth Srungarapu
v4 patch is against 0.98, attaching patch for master and branch-1
Going to commit tomorrow unless objection

I'm finding it a bit confusing the UI changes use 'msec' to mean microseconds (e.g. should that be "usec"). What about showing these metrics as milliseconds out to three decimal places Srikanth Srungarapu and using a unit label of "ms"? Let me put up a patch.
Pardon the last minute bikeshedding. Waiting for feedback. Will commit at the end of today if no objection.
Committed to 0.98+
